Hey Vsauce Michael here.

One thing that I don´t understand is: why is cross-cutting something new? In narrative, like in books, sometimes you have chapters or even paragraphs that both happen at the same time and they are "cross-cutting". At the same time, also in theater sometimes you can have two scenes happen at the same time. For example on one side of the stage there is an event going on, and then on the other side another one happening simultaneously. So I think it was just matter of time till this technique would be introduced to the public.

4:19 That's actually not parallel action, and not why Fireman was so revolutionary. What happens is that we cut back and forth between the firemen racing through the streets and the woman alone in the burning room. People understood that this is happening at the same time, we jump between the problem and the hopeful solution, and viewers got really fired up about that. And that is parallel action.

Hi CrashCourse, I'd like to fact check a claim in this video.
From what I remember from film school, Edwin Power did not invent the cross cutting technique. The original 1903 version of "Life of an American Fireman", contains no cross cutting. The film is later re-edited by unknown source.
Would you double check the claim and see into the detail of this claim? Thank you :) Keep up the good work!

When a camera pans, it moves in a horizontal plane, but it rotates around a vertical axis. When it tilts, it rotates around a horizontal axis. Not the other way around.

I don't think your description of cross-cutting is accurate to the way the technique is typically used today. The way you describe it, we get a shot of location A whose position on the in-universe timeline is from t=0 to t=5, then a shot of location B that depicts t=0 to t=5, then A from 5 to 10, then B from 5 to 10; whereas the actual use is more like A from 0 to 5, B from 5 to 10, A from 10 to 15, B from 15 to 20. So the shots aren't actually simultaneous: if the camera is like a human observer, then we are teleporting from place to place, but not also travelling back in time with each cut.
